About Us Panhellenic CouncilAwardsHistoryAlumnae AdvisorsRelationship with UBC

About Us

UBC Sororities has been enhancing the university experience for more than 80 years. From friendships, academics and athletics to community involvement and leader development, our eight sororities offer female students a place to belong while making their mark on campus.

MEET YOUR MATCH

Coming to a new campus can be overwhelming. Don’t fret! UBC Sororities allows members to become part of a smaller community full of dynamic, diverse women. From sisterhood socials and yearly retreats to fraternity exchanges and gala events, our members make the most of their university experience – complete with meaningful friendships that last through graduation and beyond, thanks to an extensive network of alumnae across North America.

MAKE THE GRADE

Academic excellence is a common goal at UBC Sororities. Our members strive for success in all they do, especially their studies. Each of our eight sororities offers unique scholarship programming, including study groups and academic mentoring. Need help selecting classes? Have a late-night study session on the agenda? You won’t be alone!

KNOW THE SCORE

Whether it’s on the field or in the gym, the members of UBC Sororities make formidable foes. We place a strong emphasis on healthy, active living, with opportunities for members of all athletic abilities to get involved and have fun. Each of our eight sororities participates in UBC Rec programming, earning points during the academic year through women’s and co-rec leagues and events. Test your skills at a new sport – you might surprise yourself!

GIVE BACK

UBC Sororities recognizes the importance of community involvement. Each of our eight sororities is affiliated with a local and/or international charity, hosting fun, interactive fundraising events in support of their specific cause each year. Collectively, our members raised over $55,000 and donated more than 19,000 volunteer hours last year – no small feat for a group of 600 women! Imagine the kind of impact you could make with their support.

LEAD, DON’T FOLLOW

The women of UBC Sororities are known for taking charge! Each of our eight sororities offer a wide range of leadership opportunities, through which members develop skills and gain experience that enables them to excel on- and off-campus. Add opportunities to serve on the UBC Sororities Council and at member-exclusive events to the mix and you’re sure to find a role that’s right for you.

How to join

The best way to join a sorority is to review our site to learn what membership entails and then participate in Formal Recruitment.

How to Join

FORMAL Recruitment 2012

Fall recruitment is comprised of four events, or ‘rounds,’ where you will get to meet individual sorority members and learn more about our eight member groups. After each round, all eight sororities submit lists of women they would like to invite back and the UBC Sororities council accepts or declines these invitations based on feedback submitted by each potential new member. ‘Bids’ or membership invitations are issued on Bid Day.

Formal recruitment for sororities happens each year in September. We are pleased to announce the dates of Formal Recruitment 2012:

TOURS: (attend ONE of the two)

Saturday, September 15th, 2012 OR Sunday, September 16th, 2012

9:30 AM – 4:00 PM

During Tours, you will get to meet each of the eight sororities for twenty minutes each. You will have the opportunity to learn about each chapter’s activities, philanthropy, athletics and most importantly, you will get to meet the women of UBC Sororities!

INVITATIONALS:

Wednesday, September 19th, 2012

5:30 PM – 10:15 PM

During Invitationals, you will be invited back to up to five sororities for thirty minutes each. You will have the opportunity to ask more questions about the chapters and meet even more women.

PREFERENCE:

Saturday, September 22nd, 2012

9:30 AM – 12:30 PM OR 11:30 AM- 2:30 PM

During Preference, you will have the chance to attend up to two 45-minute parties. This is the most personal party where you will learn what makes each chapter truly special. The chapters will have a small ceremony at the end of their party to express the values upon which their organizations were founded.

BID DAY:

Sunday, September 23rd, 2012

9:30 AM – 12:00 noon followed by chapter activities

Bid day is when you receive your bid (invitation to membership) and celebrate with your new sisters! After a brief Panhellenic-wide Bid Day celebration, you will go off with your new sisters for whichever fun activities they have planned for the day!

REGISTER HERE!



Follow us on Facebook and Twitter for updates on recruitment opportunities!

News Panhellenic Pulse

Why I Joined A Sorority

Saturday, Aug 4, 2012

Hi everyone! My name is Kate, and I’m a fifth year political science major. I’m also the Director of External Communications for UBC Sororities – meaning I’m the one tasked with managing our social media feeds, helping out our Vice President Public Relations with her many duties, and writing the news blog for our website! We wanted to give our readers a behind-the-scenes look at life as a sorority member, and since joining two years ago, I’ve compiled some great stories to tell. I’ll be updating this blog once a week through our Fall Recruitment this September, so check back for new posts about my take on UBC Sororities.

[more]

UBC Sororities Update

Friday, Apr 6, 2012

Send Off Seniors

On behalf of UBC Sororities and Panhellenic Council, we would like to congratulate all of the graduating seniors for 2012! We hope that your university and sorority experience has been amazing and we look forward to the great things to come from all of our graduating members in the very near future. Also, congratulations to all of the chapters and individuals who won awards during our Send Off Seniors Ceremony!

UBC Greek Week

UBC Greek Week 2012 was an incredible way to show to campus how great Greek really is! Greek Week is a week long period of Greek festivities in which UBC Sororities and Fraternities, pair up and team together to participate in events.

[more]

Philanthropy News

Tuesday, Mar 27, 2012

Gamma Phi Beta presents Spagammi

Join the Sisters of Gamma Phi Beta as they kick off their very first Spagammi spaghetti dinner. On, Wednesday, April 4, they will be selling plates of spaghetti, with all proceeds going to the Girl Guides of Canada. There will be a competition to see which sorority and which fraternity can raise the most money. So cancel your dinner plans for April 4th and we hope to see you at Spagammi!

UBC Sororities Update

Monday, Mar 12, 2012

Triad Tea

Alpha Gamma Delta, Alpha Phi, and Gamma Phi Beta celebrated their annual Triad Tea on February 29. These three sororities were all founded at Syracuse University and are known as the ‘Syracuse Triad.’ The annual tea is to commemorate their common bond, enjoy great company and to share their experiences that they have had altogether. We hope you were able to meet new people and that you had a great time!

All Panhellenic Exchange

On March 7, all the sororities on campus participated in an all Panhellenic exchange! Chapter rooms were divided by faculties and were transformed into study rooms.

[more]

International Badge Day

Sunday, Mar 4, 2012

International Badge Day was established in 1997 by the National Panhellenic Conference to set aside a day for women throughout the world to wear their sorority badges or Greek letters in a celebration of sisterhood.

This year’s theme is: “Wear Your Letters on Your Heart.”

UBC Sororities is excited to celebrate this day on Monday, March 5, 2012, by wearing our badge and showing that “No matter the letter, we are all Greek together.”

Philanthropy News

Tuesday, Feb 7, 2012

Alpha Phi’s Phi’bruary

‘Phi’bruary’ has just begun and the Sisters of Alpha Phi have a variety of fun events planned. Among the festivities is their signature philanthropy event ‘Dating Game’ which will be held on Thursday, February 9. The event, which gets its name from the 60′s style TV show, is essentially a game of matchmaking. Whether you’re an audience member or contestant you are guaranteed a good laugh! All proceeds will go to the Alpha Phi Foundation and the Heart and Stroke Foundation.

Alpha Gamma Delta’s Alpha Race

The sisters of Alpha Gamma Delta will be hosting their annual philanthropy event, Alpha Race on Sunday, February 12 in support of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.

[more]

UBC Sororities Update

Tuesday, Jan 31, 2012

January has been a very busy month for UBC Sororities, but it is nothing that we can’t handle!

Congratulations!

Congratulations to all of the sororities who have participated in Spring Recruitment. We welcome you to UBC Sororities and we hope you experience everything the Greek system has to offer; from leadership opportunities to countless philanthropies, we hope you enjoy every minute of being a part of a once in a lifetime experience. Thank you to everyone who was involved with the success of the very first Spring Recruitment.

Delta Gamma Anchor Splash

What a splash!

[more]

Formal Recruitment Registration

Tuesday, Aug 2, 2011

Registration for Formal Recruitment 2011 is officially open!  Have a look at our How to Join section and stay informed by following us on twitter!

Philanthropy News

Monday, Nov 8, 2010

A huge congrats to one of our sororities for raising over $18,000 for the Canadian Diabetes Association. That’s enough money to send 18 kids with Type 1 diabetes to Camp Kakhamela, a program dedicated to providing a quality summer camp experience while teaching campers about diabetes.

All of our sororities host amazing philanthropy events to raise money and awareness for a number of great causes. To keep updated about upcoming events and to find out how you can get involved, join us on Facebook.

Pride of Panhellenic

Saturday, Oct 23, 2010

We are very excited to announce that Stacy Nadeau from Dove’s Campaign for Real Beauty will be the guest speaker at this year’s Pride of Panhellenic. Every year we have a luncheon to celebrate all of our new members and this year we are very fortunate to have Stacy join us and share about her experience and address issues affecting young women everywhere, namely body image and self esteem.

Congrats & Welcome

Monday, Sep 20, 2010

We had an amazing turnout this year and we hope everyone enjoyed this experience as much as we did! Congratulations to all the sororities on a successful recruitment.

To all the new members, welcome to the Greek System!! We look forward to seeing you at our Pride of Panhellenic event happening later this term.

Back to School

Wednesday, Sep 1, 2010

Better start your countdown…there is less than one week left until the first day of school! We have tons of free giveaways and events happening soon. Check out the Events page or our Facebook fanpage for details.

New Brand Unveiled

Friday, Aug 6, 2010

Like our new look?

Over the past several months we have been working hard to develop a new brand to accurately represent UBC Sororities to the world! Tell us what you think of our new logo, website and promotional materials on our Facebook fanpage.

Housing Alumnae Panhellenic

Housing

The Panhellenic House opened in September 2004 and was designed as a campus housing complex for sorority members. It is located in the Greek Village at 2770 Wesbrook Mall, and is close to the University Village, public transit, and academic buildings.

The main floor of the building is comprised of meeting rooms for each of the eight sororities. Each meeting room reflects the personality of the sorority. With kitchen facilities, private patios, and a cozy atmosphere, the chapter room is regarded as a welcoming place to study, go for lunch, or just hang out.

The top three floors of the building are devoted to the residential component of the Panhellenic House. The residence accommodates 72 female students in 18 quad-style apartments. Each quad has four private bedrooms, a shared kitchen, dining room, living room, full bathroom, powder room, and common storage closet. Laundry facilities and bike storage are located in the basement of the building, and parking is available nearby.

If you are interested in applying for residence in the Panhellenic House, please visit the Vancouver Alumnae Panhellenic Association (VAPA) website to find out more.

For Parents

For Parents

UBC offers many options for students to become involved in campus life, and becoming a part of the largest and most active sorority communities in Canada is one of the best ways! We encourage you to learn more about UBC Sororities and to consider why every year more than 80,000 students across North America choose to become members of sororities.

Greek-letter organizations were first established at the University of British Columbia in 1926 with the goals of fostering academic excellence, leadership, the promotion of friendship, and an active commitment to community service and long-standing traditions which continue to be upheld today. UBC Sororities is comprised of eight sororities, fully recognized by the University of British Columbia. While each organization maintains its own activities, traditions, and international affiliations, each is founded on similar principles of scholarship, leadership, community service, and lifelong friendship.

Here are some answers to frequently asked questions that parents have regarding sorority life and their daughters’ experiences at UBC:

What are sororities?

How will joining a sorority now benefit my daughter after graduation?

How does my daughter get involved?

What is my role as a parent?

What will my daughter get out of a sorority that she would not get out of any other university organization?

Will my daughter’s academics be compromised if she joins a sorority?

How much time does a sorority take?

Won’t working while in school conflict with participation in a sorority?

What about alcohol use?

What about hazing?

What does it cost to be a member?

Is housing available?

What are sororities?

Greek-letter social organizations at North American universities are commonly referred to as sororities for female groups. Since the founding of the first sorority in 1851, these organizations have thrived and multiplied into hundreds of international organizations while making a positive and tremendous impact on the service and social structure of higher education systems throughout Canada and the United States. Sororities form a proven support network to help young women with the daunting transition from high school to university.

How will joining a sorority now benefit my daughter after graduation?

The lifelong friendships your daughter will make through her sorority will last into post-graduation years. International networks exist for sorority members to use for careers and job relocations. Joining a sorority really is an investment in your child’s future. Wherever she ends up after university, chances are she will be able to find an alumnae chapter or other members of her sorority in the area.

How does my daughter get involved?

Students join sororities by participating in Formal Recruitment, which takes place in September. Joining a sorority is a process of mutual selection with the goal of providing the best place for everyone. Your daughter may register for Formal Recruitment via the registration page on this site.

What is my role as a parent?

By taking the time to read through this section of the website, you have already begun to take the time to learn more about UBC Sororities! During Formal Recruitment, your daughter will be making important decisions about which sorority is best suited for her; this decision is not an easy one to make and as a parent your support and encouragement is crucial. Ask questions about what the different sororities can offer your daughter, and guide her into making the best decision for her.

What will my daughter get out of a sorority that she would not get out of any other university organization?

Coming to university is one of the major life changes that your daughter will go through. Joining a sorority helps students to acclimate to campus life more quickly, and provides them with a structured atmosphere in which they can concentrate on scholarship, leadership, and service. Developing lifelong friendships with the members in her sorority helps make the campus smaller. For many members, their sorority becomes a home away from home.

Your daughter will also find personal growth and development extending far beyond her years on campus. A sorority can help personalize your daughter’s university experience by offering hands-on experience in leading committees, managing budgets, and interacting with faculty and administrators. Each year, sorority members contribute thousands of dollars and hundreds of hours of volunteer time to community service projects in the Lower Mainland. UBC’s sorority members are also heavily involved on the campus and hold many prominent leadership positions in the Alma Mater Society (student government), campus clubs and athletics. This involvement helps students to develop leadership skills that are beneficial to securing employment after graduation.

Current members also cite alumnae support as one of the unique benefits of joining a sorority. Alumnae provide networking opportunities for students, which help them to secure internships and jobs throughout and after their university careers. In addition, many alumnae are actively involved as advisors, providing additional support for the transition to university life.

Will my daughter’s academics be compromised if she joins a sorority?

Actually, it is more likely that a sorority will help your daughter’s grades. When a student joins a sorority, she becomes a part of a larger group of students who have already made it through their first year at UBC. Not only does this group understand what a first-year student is facing, but they can also provide assistance in most of the courses your daughter will be taking. Each sorority has a scholarship officer who initiates programs to encourage high academic achievement. With the broad range of resources available students are more likely to achieve their academic potential.

How much time does a sorority take?

The time commitment varies from sorority to sorority, but the first term is the most time-intensive as the new member goes through the chapter’s Education Program. The time spent in this program will give your daughter the opportunity to develop her leadership and time management skills, learn about the history of her organization, develop friendships with her new member class as well as the rest of the sorority, and allow her to become involved with other organizations. After initiation into the sorority, expectations will vary. Each sorority has weekly meetings and other mandatory events, such as community service projects throughout the year, but they are planned well in advance. In addition to the weekly meeting, the more your daughter puts into the sorority the more she will get out of being a member!

Won’t working while in school conflict with participation in a sorority?

Many students involved in a sorority also hold part-time employment. In today’s world, the reality is that only the lucky few can afford to attend university without outside employment. Sororities recognize that it is important for members to be able to meet their financial obligations and that many students will work to help finance their educations. Working students can still take advantage of the opportunities available through UBC Sororities.

What about alcohol use?

In accordance with the National Panhellenic Conference (NPC) Alcohol Initiative, joint sorority/fraternity events held on fraternity property are alcohol-free. All sorority meeting rooms in the Panhellenic House are alcohol-free. Sorority members also benefit from alcohol and drug abuse seminars as well as educational programs on date rape, assault and safety.

What about hazing?

Hazing, or any activity that subjects members to harassment, ridicule, intimidation, physical exhaustion or mental distress is entirely contrary to the purposes of a sorority and the University and is not permitted or tolerated. Sorority members are educated on the dangers of such practices on an ongoing basis.

What does it cost to be a member?

Sororities are quite affordable; in fact, the financial commitment is typically less than what a student would spend on housing and entertainment as a non-member. Each sorority is responsible for setting the costs for membership, so the fees vary by sorority. Dues go to services that will positively impact your daughter, and directly support the betterment of the sorority and the international organization. The sorority experience is an investment in your daughter’s future. The leadership skills, the academic assistance, and friendships will benefit your daughter beyond her university days. The perception that sororities are only an option for the wealthy is widespread and false. To assist members, sororities may offer various scholarships and grants. Please encourage your daughter to ask about costs during formal recruitment.

Is housing available?

Located in the Greek Village on campus, the Panhellenic House provides housing for members as well as meeting facilities. The Panhellenic House is owned and operated by the Vancouver Alumnae Panhellenic Association (VAPA), a non-profit organization comprised of alumnae of each sorority. VAPA ensures that the facility is a safe place for students to live. Visit our Housing page to learn more.


For further information about sorority life, feel free to have a look at the National Panhellenic Conference website and SororityParents.com

How to join

The best way to join a sorority is to review our site to learn what membership entails and then participate in Formal Recruitment.

FAQ Greek GlossaryRecruitment

FAQ

Are sororities just like the ones on TV or in the movies?

What is the time commitment for a sorority?

If I choose to join a sorority, how will I cover the membership dues?

Is housing available?

I’m interested but still not sure!


Are sororities just like the ones on TV or in the movies?

Each sorority is different. UBC has eight sororities, all with unique characteristics and diverse women. The images portrayed on TV or in movies do not reflect the attitude of the sororities at UBC. We stand for leadership, friendship, scholarship, charity and social development.

What is the time commitment for a sorority?

Each sorority has different events that are considered mandatory. In general, each organization requires a commitment every Wednesday night for chapter meetings, and a few other days throughout each semester for special events. In your first term as a member, you will also participate in your sorority’s membership education program, where you will learn about your sorority’s history, structure, and the responsibilities and privileges of membership. Your participation in Greek life should not detract from your responsibilities; in fact, the majority of members manage to hold down jobs and focus on their studies while still having an active presence in their chapters.

If I choose to join a sorority, how will I cover the membership dues?

Like any organization, sororities require fees to put on great programs and activities for their members. However, unlike many clubs, sororities have various scholarships and payment plans to assist in covering these costs. Ask the sorority members you meet during formal recruitment about what payment options are offered. Financial concerns should not keep any student from joining a sorority.

Is housing available?

Both fraternities and sororities offer affordable housing options to their members. Each fraternity has its own house located either in the Greek Village or centrally along Wesbrook Mall. The Greek Village is also home to the Panhellenic House, which offers apartment-style residences for sorority women. While Greek housing provides an excellent residential experience on campus, it is not a requirement of membership.

I’m interested but still not sure!

Visit other areas of the UBC Sororities website, check out each sorority’s chapter website or email us at info@ubcsororities.com. Also, be sure to visit our recruitment booth set up outside the SUB during the first week of school. We are here to help you and we would love to hear from you!

How to join

The best way to join a sorority is to review our site to learn what membership entails and then participate in Formal Recruitment.

News Panhellenic Pulse

Why I Joined A Sorority

Saturday, Aug 4, 2012

Hi everyone! My name is Kate, and I’m a fifth year political science major. I’m also the Director of External Communications for UBC Sororities – meaning I’m the one tasked with managing our social media feeds, helping out our Vice President Public Relations with her many duties, and writing the news blog for our website! We wanted to give our readers a behind-the-scenes look at life as a sorority member, and since joining two years ago, I’ve compiled some great stories to tell. I’ll be updating this blog once a week through our Fall Recruitment this September, so check back for new posts about my take on UBC Sororities.

[more]

UBC Sororities Update

Friday, Apr 6, 2012

Send Off Seniors

On behalf of UBC Sororities and Panhellenic Council, we would like to congratulate all of the graduating seniors for 2012! We hope that your university and sorority experience has been amazing and we look forward to the great things to come from all of our graduating members in the very near future. Also, congratulations to all of the chapters and individuals who won awards during our Send Off Seniors Ceremony!

UBC Greek Week

UBC Greek Week 2012 was an incredible way to show to campus how great Greek really is! Greek Week is a week long period of Greek festivities in which UBC Sororities and Fraternities, pair up and team together to participate in events.

[more]

Philanthropy News

Tuesday, Mar 27, 2012

Gamma Phi Beta presents Spagammi

Join the Sisters of Gamma Phi Beta as they kick off their very first Spagammi spaghetti dinner. On, Wednesday, April 4, they will be selling plates of spaghetti, with all proceeds going to the Girl Guides of Canada. There will be a competition to see which sorority and which fraternity can raise the most money. So cancel your dinner plans for April 4th and we hope to see you at Spagammi!

UBC Sororities Update

Monday, Mar 12, 2012

Triad Tea

Alpha Gamma Delta, Alpha Phi, and Gamma Phi Beta celebrated their annual Triad Tea on February 29. These three sororities were all founded at Syracuse University and are known as the ‘Syracuse Triad.’ The annual tea is to commemorate their common bond, enjoy great company and to share their experiences that they have had altogether. We hope you were able to meet new people and that you had a great time!

All Panhellenic Exchange

On March 7, all the sororities on campus participated in an all Panhellenic exchange! Chapter rooms were divided by faculties and were transformed into study rooms.

[more]

International Badge Day

Sunday, Mar 4, 2012

International Badge Day was established in 1997 by the National Panhellenic Conference to set aside a day for women throughout the world to wear their sorority badges or Greek letters in a celebration of sisterhood.

This year’s theme is: “Wear Your Letters on Your Heart.”

UBC Sororities is excited to celebrate this day on Monday, March 5, 2012, by wearing our badge and showing that “No matter the letter, we are all Greek together.”

Philanthropy News

Tuesday, Feb 7, 2012

Alpha Phi’s Phi’bruary

‘Phi’bruary’ has just begun and the Sisters of Alpha Phi have a variety of fun events planned. Among the festivities is their signature philanthropy event ‘Dating Game’ which will be held on Thursday, February 9. The event, which gets its name from the 60′s style TV show, is essentially a game of matchmaking. Whether you’re an audience member or contestant you are guaranteed a good laugh! All proceeds will go to the Alpha Phi Foundation and the Heart and Stroke Foundation.

Alpha Gamma Delta’s Alpha Race

The sisters of Alpha Gamma Delta will be hosting their annual philanthropy event, Alpha Race on Sunday, February 12 in support of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation.

UBC Sororities Update

Tuesday, Jan 31, 2012

January has been a very busy month for UBC Sororities, but it is nothing that we can’t handle!

Congratulations!

Congratulations to all of the sororities who have participated in Spring Recruitment. We welcome you to UBC Sororities and we hope you experience everything the Greek system has to offer; from leadership opportunities to countless philanthropies, we hope you enjoy every minute of being a part of a once in a lifetime experience. Thank you to everyone who was involved with the success of the very first Spring Recruitment.

Formal Recruitment Registration

Tuesday, Aug 2, 2011

Registration for Formal Recruitment 2011 is officially open!  Have a look at our How to Join section and stay informed by following us on twitter!

Philanthropy News

Monday, Nov 8, 2010

A huge congrats to one of our sororities for raising over $18,000 for the Canadian Diabetes Association. That’s enough money to send 18 kids with Type 1 diabetes to Camp Kakhamela, a program dedicated to providing a quality summer camp experience while teaching campers about diabetes.

All of our sororities host amazing philanthropy events to raise money and awareness for a number of great causes. To keep updated about upcoming events and to find out how you can get involved, join us on Facebook.

Pride of Panhellenic

Saturday, Oct 23, 2010

We are very excited to announce that Stacy Nadeau from Dove’s Campaign for Real Beauty will be the guest speaker at this year’s Pride of Panhellenic. Every year we have a luncheon to celebrate all of our new members and this year we are very fortunate to have Stacy join us and share about her experience and address issues affecting young women everywhere, namely body image and self esteem.

Congrats & Welcome

Monday, Sep 20, 2010

We had an amazing turnout this year and we hope everyone enjoyed this experience as much as we did! Congratulations to all the sororities on a successful recruitment.

To all the new members, welcome to the Greek System!! We look forward to seeing you at our Pride of Panhellenic event happening later this term.

Back to School

Wednesday, Sep 1, 2010

Better start your countdown…there is less than one week left until the first day of school! We have tons of free giveaways and events happening soon. Check out the Events page or our Facebook fanpage for details.

New Brand Unveiled

Friday, Aug 6, 2010

Like our new look?

Over the past several months we have been working hard to develop a new brand to accurately represent UBC Sororities to the world! Tell us what you think of our new logo, website and promotional materials on our Facebook fanpage.

Housing Alumnae Panhellenic

Housing

The Panhellenic House opened in September 2004 and was designed as a campus housing complex for sorority members. It is located in the Greek Village at 2770 Wesbrook Mall, and is close to the University Village, public transit, and academic buildings.

The main floor of the building is comprised of meeting rooms for each of the eight sororities. Each meeting room reflects the personality of the sorority. With kitchen facilities, private patios, and a cozy atmosphere, the chapter room is regarded as a welcoming place to study, go for lunch, or just hang out.

The top three floors of the building are devoted to the residential component of the Panhellenic House. The residence accommodates 72 female students in 18 quad-style apartments. Each quad has four private bedrooms, a shared kitchen, dining room, living room, full bathroom, powder room, and common storage closet. Laundry facilities and bike storage are located in the basement of the building, and parking is available nearby.

If you are interested in applying for residence in the Panhellenic House, please visit the Vancouver Alumnae Panhellenic Association (VAPA) website to find out more.

For Parents

For Parents

UBC offers many options for students to become involved in campus life, and becoming a part of the largest and most active sorority communities in Canada is one of the best ways! We encourage you to learn more about UBC Sororities and to consider why every year more than 80,000 students across North America choose to become members of sororities.

Greek-letter organizations were first established at the University of British Columbia in 1926 with the goals of fostering academic excellence, leadership, the promotion of friendship, and an active commitment to community service and long-standing traditions which continue to be upheld today. UBC Sororities is comprised of eight sororities, fully recognized by the University of British Columbia. While each organization maintains its own activities, traditions, and international affiliations, each is founded on similar principles of scholarship, leadership, community service, and lifelong friendship.

Here are some answers to frequently asked questions that parents have regarding sorority life and their daughters’ experiences at UBC:

What are sororities?

How will joining a sorority now benefit my daughter after graduation?

How does my daughter get involved?

What is my role as a parent?

What will my daughter get out of a sorority that she would not get out of any other university organization?

Will my daughter’s academics be compromised if she joins a sorority?

How much time does a sorority take?

Won’t working while in school conflict with participation in a sorority?

What about alcohol use?

What about hazing?

What does it cost to be a member?

Is housing available?

What are sororities?

Greek-letter social organizations at North American universities are commonly referred to as sororities for female groups. Since the founding of the first sorority in 1851, these organizations have thrived and multiplied into hundreds of international organizations while making a positive and tremendous impact on the service and social structure of higher education systems throughout Canada and the United States. Sororities form a proven support network to help young women with the daunting transition from high school to university.

How will joining a sorority now benefit my daughter after graduation?

The lifelong friendships your daughter will make through her sorority will last into post-graduation years. International networks exist for sorority members to use for careers and job relocations. Joining a sorority really is an investment in your child’s future. Wherever she ends up after university, chances are she will be able to find an alumnae chapter or other members of her sorority in the area.

How does my daughter get involved?

Students join sororities by participating in Formal Recruitment, which takes place in September. Joining a sorority is a process of mutual selection with the goal of providing the best place for everyone. Your daughter may register for Formal Recruitment via the registration page on this site.

What is my role as a parent?

By taking the time to read through this section of the website, you have already begun to take the time to learn more about UBC Sororities! During Formal Recruitment, your daughter will be making important decisions about which sorority is best suited for her; this decision is not an easy one to make and as a parent your support and encouragement is crucial. Ask questions about what the different sororities can offer your daughter, and guide her into making the best decision for her.

What will my daughter get out of a sorority that she would not get out of any other university organization?

Coming to university is one of the major life changes that your daughter will go through. Joining a sorority helps students to acclimate to campus life more quickly, and provides them with a structured atmosphere in which they can concentrate on scholarship, leadership, and service. Developing lifelong friendships with the members in her sorority helps make the campus smaller. For many members, their sorority becomes a home away from home.

Your daughter will also find personal growth and development extending far beyond her years on campus. A sorority can help personalize your daughter’s university experience by offering hands-on experience in leading committees, managing budgets, and interacting with faculty and administrators. Each year, sorority members contribute thousands of dollars and hundreds of hours of volunteer time to community service projects in the Lower Mainland. UBC’s sorority members are also heavily involved on the campus and hold many prominent leadership positions in the Alma Mater Society (student government), campus clubs and athletics. This involvement helps students to develop leadership skills that are beneficial to securing employment after graduation.

Current members also cite alumnae support as one of the unique benefits of joining a sorority. Alumnae provide networking opportunities for students, which help them to secure internships and jobs throughout and after their university careers. In addition, many alumnae are actively involved as advisors, providing additional support for the transition to university life.

Will my daughter’s academics be compromised if she joins a sorority?

Actually, it is more likely that a sorority will help your daughter’s grades. When a student joins a sorority, she becomes a part of a larger group of students who have already made it through their first year at UBC. Not only does this group understand what a first-year student is facing, but they can also provide assistance in most of the courses your daughter will be taking. Each sorority has a scholarship officer who initiates programs to encourage high academic achievement. With the broad range of resources available students are more likely to achieve their academic potential.

How much time does a sorority take?

The time commitment varies from sorority to sorority, but the first term is the most time-intensive as the new member goes through the chapter’s Education Program. The time spent in this program will give your daughter the opportunity to develop her leadership and time management skills, learn about the history of her organization, develop friendships with her new member class as well as the rest of the sorority, and allow her to become involved with other organizations. After initiation into the sorority, expectations will vary. Each sorority has weekly meetings and other mandatory events, such as community service projects throughout the year, but they are planned well in advance. In addition to the weekly meeting, the more your daughter puts into the sorority the more she will get out of being a member!

Won’t working while in school conflict with participation in a sorority?

Many students involved in a sorority also hold part-time employment. In today’s world, the reality is that only the lucky few can afford to attend university without outside employment. Sororities recognize that it is important for members to be able to meet their financial obligations and that many students will work to help finance their educations. Working students can still take advantage of the opportunities available through UBC Sororities.

What about alcohol use?

In accordance with the National Panhellenic Conference (NPC) Alcohol Initiative, joint sorority/fraternity events held on fraternity property are alcohol-free. All sorority meeting rooms in the Panhellenic House are alcohol-free. Sorority members also benefit from alcohol and drug abuse seminars as well as educational programs on date rape, assault and safety.

What about hazing?

Hazing, or any activity that subjects members to harassment, ridicule, intimidation, physical exhaustion or mental distress is entirely contrary to the purposes of a sorority and the University and is not permitted or tolerated. Sorority members are educated on the dangers of such practices on an ongoing basis.

What does it cost to be a member?

Sororities are quite affordable; in fact, the financial commitment is typically less than what a student would spend on housing and entertainment as a non-member. Each sorority is responsible for setting the costs for membership, so the fees vary by sorority. Dues go to services that will positively impact your daughter, and directly support the betterment of the sorority and the international organization. The sorority experience is an investment in your daughter’s future. The leadership skills, the academic assistance, and friendships will benefit your daughter beyond her university days. The perception that sororities are only an option for the wealthy is widespread and false. To assist members, sororities may offer various scholarships and grants. Please encourage your daughter to ask about costs during formal recruitment.

Is housing available?

Located in the Greek Village on campus, the Panhellenic House provides housing for members as well as meeting facilities. The Panhellenic House is owned and operated by the Vancouver Alumnae Panhellenic Association (VAPA), a non-profit organization comprised of alumnae of each sorority. VAPA ensures that the facility is a safe place for students to live. Visit our Housing page to learn more.


For further information about sorority life, feel free to have a look at the National Panhellenic Conference website and SororityParents.com

FAQ Greek GlossaryRecruitment

FAQ

Are sororities just like the ones on TV or in the movies?

What is the time commitment for a sorority?

If I choose to join a sorority, how will I cover the membership dues?

Is housing available?

I’m interested but still not sure!


Are sororities just like the ones on TV or in the movies?

Each sorority is different. UBC has eight sororities, all with unique characteristics and diverse women. The images portrayed on TV or in movies do not reflect the attitude of the sororities at UBC. We stand for leadership, friendship, scholarship, charity and social development.

What is the time commitment for a sorority?

Each sorority has different events that are considered mandatory. In general, each organization requires a commitment every Wednesday night for chapter meetings, and a few other days throughout each semester for special events. In your first term as a member, you will also participate in your sorority’s membership education program, where you will learn about your sorority’s history, structure, and the responsibilities and privileges of membership. Your participation in Greek life should not detract from your responsibilities; in fact, the majority of members manage to hold down jobs and focus on their studies while still having an active presence in their chapters.

If I choose to join a sorority, how will I cover the membership dues?

Like any organization, sororities require fees to put on great programs and activities for their members. However, unlike many clubs, sororities have various scholarships and payment plans to assist in covering these costs. Ask the sorority members you meet during formal recruitment about what payment options are offered. Financial concerns should not keep any student from joining a sorority.

Is housing available?

Both fraternities and sororities offer affordable housing options to their members. Each fraternity has its own house located either in the Greek Village or centrally along Wesbrook Mall. The Greek Village is also home to the Panhellenic House, which offers apartment-style residences for sorority women. While Greek housing provides an excellent residential experience on campus, it is not a requirement of membership.

I’m interested but still not sure!

Visit other areas of the UBC Sororities website, check out each sorority’s chapter website or email us at info@ubcsororities.com. Also, be sure to visit our recruitment booth set up outside the SUB during the first week of school. We are here to help you and we would love to hear from you!
